snippet: Some see a promise to free Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar as an act of good will toward Afghanistan, while others worry it is an attempt to shape regional power dynamics.
abstract: Pakistani officials say they are ready to release Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, imprisoned senior Taliban commander, in bid to bolster faltering peace process in Afghanistan; release of Baradar, who was captured by CIA in 2010, would meet longstanding demands from American and Afghan officials, who hope he can draw other Taliban commanders into peace talks.

byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH and ROD NORDLAND
byline.contributor: Declan Walsh reported from London, and Rod Nordland from Kabul, Afghanistan. Reporting was contributed by Salman Masood from Islamabad, Pakistan, Matthew Rosenberg from Washington, and Sharifullah Sahak and Jawad Sukhanyar from Kabul.

lead_paragraph: Some see a promise to free Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar as an act of good will toward Afghanistan, while others worry it is an attempt to shape regional power dynamics.

headline.main: Pakistan May Release Taliban Commander to Aid Afghan Peace Talks
headline.print_headline: Pakistan May Release Taliban Commander to Aid Afghan Peace Talks
